South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

ADVERTISEMENTS.– P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20, every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news columns P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.
N.B.– Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.
SUBSCRIPTIONS and ADVERTISEMENTS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria.
London Offices: 86, New Broad-street, E.C.
THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE” IS PRINTED ON PAPER MANUFACTURED AND SUPPLIED BY THE LONDON PAPER MILLS Co., LIMITED (SALES OFFICE: 27, CANNON STREET, E.C.) 25-6-90

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880.
Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.
Price: One Piastre Tariff.
WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 26, 1904.

div.head: THE ASSOUAN DAM AND THE TEMPLES
div.p: The decision of the Government to raise the Assouan Dam has again brought forward the question of the possible damage that will ensue to Philae and the Nubian Temples, and a correspondence on this subject is. appearing in the T'imes. In to day's issue we reproduce a letter from Sir William Preece in reply to a letter : which we printed yesterday wherein.a parallel is drawn between the intentions of Sir William Garstin and the Anglo-Egyptian- irri- gation experts in this. matter and those of Torquemada, Robespierre, and the Communards, and the writer goes on to state that "until the ealet engineer has publicly proved that no lternatiye to his plans is possible, and that he'is not merely oheapening: by destruction, he must be classed as a public dauger."

On reading the furious outpourings of F. R. S." many will perhaps be reminded of he famous invective of Ruskin's, "You have lespised Nature , that ih to say, all the deep nd sacred sensations of natufal soenery. The 'rench. revolutionista made stables of the athedrals of., Franoe; yon have made race- ourses of the cathedrals of the earth. Your ne oonoeption of pleasure is to drive in rail-road carriagesround their aisles and eat-off their altars. You have pat a railrond bridge over the fall of Schaffhausen. You, have .tun. nelled the oliffs of Lucerne by Tell's chapel ; yon have destroyed the Clarens shore of the Take of Geneva; there is nota quiet vallex in England that you haye not filled with bellowing fire ; there is no particle left of English land which you have not trampled coal-ashes into- nor any foreign city in which the spread of your presence is not marked among ita fair old streets and happy gardens by a consuming white leprosy of new hotels and perfumers' shops; the.Alps themselves,which yourown poeta used to love so reverently, you. look upon as soaped poles in a bear garden which yon set yourselves to climb, and slide down again, with 'shrieks of delight. When you are past shriek. ing, having no human articulate voice to say you are glad with, you nll. the quietude. ot their valleys with gunpowder blasts, and rush home red with cutaneous: eruption of conceit, and voluble with convulsive hiccough of self- satisfaction. , . It is pitiful to have dim conceptions of duty ;. more pitiful, it seems to me; to have conceptions like these, of thirth."

That is one aspect of the matter, It is, no doubt, exaggerated, rhetorical,' sentimental al- most to the verge of the grotesone. But it ex presses, as none, perhaps, but Ruskin conld, that melancholy antinomy, so distrossing to the r sentimentalist, which sete the slaims ofart and of Nature, of."all the deep ard.sacred sensa- tions of natural scenery," orer against the. claims of human industry and ot buman pro gress. We do not beg the question i speaking of human progress. We merely take note afthe fact that the world does move from generatin to generation, and that, whether we like it or not, we'must move with it. We'must live in our own age, not in any other ; and. Ruskin' himself, if he had but known it, was as much a creature of his age as the builders of the As. souan Dam. He could not have felt' and interpreted as he did "all the deep and' sacred sensations of natural scenery," had he. lved in the middle of. the eighteenth century ; still less, had he lived in his own beloved Middle Ages. These are sensations which have grown with the march of human progress. The quiet valleys whiose desecration he deplores were left in their quietnde, not because they were prized for their beauty by the generations of the past, but because there were few to enjoy, and none to destroy, their ancient and undisturb- ed peace. It is only in this age,. which, according to Raskin and "F.R. 'S.," despises the claims of Art and Nature in favour of base utilitarian schemes, that we would . go to such pains as to consolidate the Philae temples at the cost.of many: thousands of pounds; or to organise a special Government department for the protection of Egyptian antiquities. How ever much more Philae will 'be subinerged by the raising of the Dam the grchaeologists have only themielves to blame.The temples world have been altogether out of reach of the floods if Sir William Willedcks's plan of moving then on the Bigeh Island had been adopted, or Sir. Benjamin Baker's scheme of ralsing the teinples, like a great Chicngo hotel, clean sbove the high level of the reservoir. Neither of those proposals were agreed to. A compromise was arrived st and the level of the reservoir was lowered so that only a part of Philae should be drowned. This compromise was forcibly charseterised .by Mr. Winston Churchill na "the most oruel, the most wioked, and the most sonseless saerifice ever offered;on, the altar of a false. religion. The state . mast struggle and the people starve, in order that: professots may exult and tourista find some place on which to sertch their napies." Bud this sop to sentimentdlispi is to be withdrawn and the coantry seannot throw awny many millions of cubio metres of precious water for the sake of a handfal. of antiquarians and dilettanti.

div.head:
NORTH SEA OUTRAGE
UNIVERSAL INDIGRNATION
A DISGRACE TO RUSSIA
GOVERNMENT'S ACTION
TSAR'S SYMPATHY WITH VICTOMS
THE KING'S SORROW.
div.p: The King has telegraphed to . the Mayor of Hull expressing his profound sorrow at the unwarrantable action which has been committed against the fishing, fleet. His Majesty has given, two hundred guineas amdngst the families of the snfferers.

Mr. Balfour, in, reply to the Mayor's appeal that strong measures should be, taken, said; "You may have full confidence. in the Govern- ment's action." The indignation throughout the country is of the most intense kind.

div.head: PROTESTS TO FOREIGN OFFICE.
div.p: The assoeiations of trawler owners.at various ports have sent strongly worded protests to - the Foreign Office.
The papers, declare that an apology and compensation. are-inadequate. Russia must be asked to punish the guilty officers, and to interrupt the voyage of the Baltic Fleet ..

div.head: MISSING TRAWLERS FOUND.
div.p: All the missing trawlers are now accounted for.

div.head: RUSSIAN AMBASSADOR HOOTED.
div.p: Count Benkendorff has arrived from Germany. A small crowd hooted at the station, and a youth attempted to break the windows of the carriage.

div.head: TO THE PEOPLE OF ENGLAND.
div.p: Count Benkendorff has authorized the Daily News to inform the people of England that he is abyolntely certain the occurrence was a deplorable accident, which was. regretted by himself and his country.

div.head: INDIGNATION OF FOREIGN PRESS.
div.p: Universal indignation is expressed in the foreign Press. The German papers describe the Baltic Fleet as a disgrace to Russia, and as being in danger, if they ever rench Japanese waters, of.being sent to the bottom like paper boats.
(Reuter.)

div.head: NEWS SUPPRESSED IN RUSSIA.
div.p: The Censor: suppressed the news of the North Sea incident: The morning papers pub- lished nothing whilst the evening editions reported a collision which resulted in the sinking of. two trawlers.

Sir A. Hardinge, on his own initiative, asked for an explanation from Count Lamsdorff, who replied that his only information was derived from the London telegrams, and that the Navar Headquarters had not received any report from the Baltic Fleet.
(Reuter.)

div.head: THE BRITISH DEMANDS.
div.p: Lord Lansdowne has demanded dne apolo -. gies fromRussid, compensation, fort the safferers, prompt enquiry into the incident, and the punishment of those who 'are - respon- sible. :

div.head: RUSSIAN PRESS APOLOGETIC.
div.p: The Russian Press is disposed to. be apolo- getic but thinks that the trawlers must, some- how or other; have been at fault.
The French papers are convinced that Russia will comply with the British demands.

div.head: ORDERS TO BRITISH FLEETS.
div.p: (Official). As a measure of precaution, im- mediately the news of the incident was received, preliminary orders for mutual support and co operation were issued by the Admiralty to the Channel, Mediterranean, and Home fleets. (Reuter.)

div.head: THE TSAR'S REGRETS.
div.p: The Tsar has telegraphed to the King ex- pressing his deep regret, and his condolences with the families of the,victims. He says he has not received any news from Admiral Rojestvensky, but he could only attribute the incident to.a very regrettable mnisunderstand- ing. He will take steps to afford complete . satisfaction to the sufferers as soon as the circumstances are cleared up.

div.head: BRITISH NOTE.
div.p: Sir A. Hardinge has presented a strongly- worded Note detailing all the circumstances of the incident. He dwelt upon the inhumanity displayed in not assisting the. victims and intimated the presentation of the demands already mentioned, which were reserved pending the reply.' (Reuter.)

div.head: "A TERRIBLE MISTAKE?'
div.p: Lord Lansdowne and Count Benckerdorff had a long interview to-day. Count Benckendorff informed Reuter's Agent be was convinced that when the. faots . which the Embassy telegraphed yesterday ,evening and to-day reach St. Petersburg,, the whole difficulty will disappegr. The entire affair is a terrible mistake, which is at present. inexplie- able, and it is the more regrettable because the relations between the two countries were be coming more cordial. (Reuter.)
The trawler Snipe has arrived here with two of the wounded who were on board the Crane. She herself is badly damaged.
(Reuter.)
The Tsar has telegraphed his deep regret at the Hull fshers incident: h. (Havas.)

div.head: ANGLO-FRENCH AGREEMENT IN THE CHAMBER OF DEPUTIES
div.p: M. Delcasse will ask the Chamber.of Depu' ties to fix the 3rd. November for the discussion of the Anglo-French Agreement.
(Havas.)

div.head: ECHO OF DRIYFUS CASE.
div.p: The trial of Captain Dautrphe has begun at the Council of War.
(Havas.)

div.head: THE GREEK SQUADRON
div.p: is due at Alexandria on the Brd proxo.

div.head: IRRIGATION .-
div.p: It is stated that the Egyptias Government has sent for another English inspector from India, for irrigation works. .

div.head: STRAY AND OWNERLESS DOGs
div.p: found in the Minet-el-Bassal district during the night of the 29th inst. will be poisoned by the Alexandria police.

div.head: THE BRINDISI MAIL'
div.p: will arrive at Alexandria by this afternoon's express and will be ready for distribution at the G.P.O. at 7:45 a.m. to-morrow.

div.head: TRAMWAY' EXTENSION. --
div.p: The Alexandria Tramway Company has applied to the Municipality for permission to construct tramlines to Hadra.

div.head: AUTOMOBILE SERVICE .-
div.p: An application has been made to the Alexandria Municipality for permission to establish a service of motor omnibuses.

div.head: THE STATUE
div.p: of Ibrahim Pasha and the gates of the Esbekieh Gardens, Cairo, are being cleaned by the Tanzim authorities. Both were decidedly in need of it.

div.head: THE MINISTRY OF JUSTICE
div.p: has decided that, as from the 1st January next, the salary of the moawens of the Parquet will be raised from L.E. 10 to L.E. 12 per month.

div.head: AT THE EXHIBITION
div.p: of the Royal Society of British Artists Mr. R. Talbot Kelly has portrayed the "Courtyard of the Mosque-el-Gulshany, Cairo," in shadow that glows with reflected light.

div.head: SUPREME CONSULAR COURT .-
div.p: Judge Sausmarez is arriving from Constantinople on the 31st inst. There are no cases of importance for the sessions of the Supreme Consular Court at Alexandria.

div.head: A GREAT SENSATION
div.p: has been aroused in native circles owing to the extraordinary article in yesterday's issue of Al Liwa, wherein, the editor, Mustapha Pasha Kamel, explains his reasons for no longer keeping up his relations with the Maieh.

div.head: THE CITADEL,-
div.p: On visiting the Citadel on Monday morning H. E. the Sirdar was pleased to express to the Director of the Citadel his complete satisfaction with his inspection, which reflected great credit on the heads of departments concerned and their respective staffs.

div.head: AMERICAN CONSULATES .-
div.p: We notice that the titles of the United States Diplomatic Agency of Cairo and that of the Consular Agency at Alexandria have been changed. Henceforth the official qualification "United States" will be changed for that of "American."

div.head: ALEXANDRIA NATIVE COURT. -
div.p: The Alexandria Native Court sentenced this morning Mahrous Chubar, an inhabitant of Negras, to two years' imprisonment, for shooting and killing a native of the same village whom he canght in the act of destroying his cotton crops.

div.head: SUEZ CANAL .-
div.p: On the 22nd and 23rd inst. 24 vessels passed through the Suez Canal. Of these, 15 were British, 1 Norwegian, 5 German, 2 Austrian, and 1 French. The transit and passenger dues for the two days amounted to 706,093.52 frs. The total transit and passenger dues collected from the 1st to that date on 297 vessels amounted to 7,759,599.26 frs.

div.head: EGYPT'S FOREIGN TRADE .-
div.p: The Statistical Department of the Customs Administration has issued a most useful work, giving the fullest statisties of the foreign trade of Egypt from 1884 to 1903. The editor, Mr. Randone, deserves to be congratulated on this carefully compiled work, which contains a mine of valuable information on the trade of this country.

div.head: KUROPATKIN, IN SUPREME COMMAND.
div.p: General Kuropatkin has. been appointed to the supreme command the armies in Man- churia,
(Havas.)

div.head: JAPANESE CASUALPIES AT SHA-HO.
div.p: The Japanese total casualties at the . battle of tlie Sha-Ho amounted to 15,879. (Reuter.)

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: The Khedive is spending the day, at Montazah.
The reason' for his Highness having postponed.the date of his departure for Cairo, is that he may be at Alexandria during the visit of the Greek Squadron.

div.head: DEPARTURE OF H. L. I.
div.p: Suez, Tuesday .- The troop train conveying. the 1st Battalion Highland Light Infantry arrived at Suez Docks yesterday morning, and the troops embarked shortly after on the trans- port Sicilia, which sailed' at 2.30 in the after- noon bound to Bombay.

div.head: MILITARY SERVICE.
div.p: The revenue from the tax for relief from military service .- amounted to L.E. 13,346 during the month of September last. From the 1st January to the end of that month the tax produced .L.E. 127,766, as against. 147,036 during the corresponding period last year, showing an increase of L.E. 27,766.

div.head: THE MoMILLAN EXPEDITION.
div.p: Mr. B. H. Jesson, who accompanied Mr. McMillan's expedition, is to read a paper after Christmas before the Royal Geographical Society. He, will deal with the portion of the' Sobat basin in Abyssinia, which has not hitherto been explored.

div.head: ASSOUAN DAM AND THE TEMPLES.
div.p: Sir William Preece, the well-known electrical engineer, and formerly .Engineer-in-Chief to. the Post-Office, writes "as follows to the Times in reply to the letter of "F. R. S." which we re- produced yesterday :-

Does. it occur'to "F.R.S." (wlty will cor- respondents juse such letters of,distinction to disgnise their identity when expressing timid and. -often foolish opinion !) that the Philae temples are quite modern compared with those in Egypt! Vişitors aseending the Nile become. surfeited. with Ptolemaic and Roman parodies of pure Egyptian culture and irritated with the political . morality which threw over the beau- ties of Greek arts to foster an effete and decaying civilization. What is more ludicrous than a Roman Emperor posing as an Egyptian god.1 There is much that is beautiful in Philae, but nothing that is epoch-marking. . The kiosk of Pharaoh's, bed would be far more attractive.if erected on the south end of Elephantine Island. The other temples can remain where they are, They will be seen at Low Nile. They will not be damaged by the full reseryoir, but they will beautify a charming lake and a delightful boating resort. The outery against the heightening of the dam: is sentimental "rot.".

div.head: NEW NORTH GERMAN LLOYD STEAMER.
div.p: The new Norddeutscher Lloyd Imperial Mail steamship Prinz. Eitel Friedrich (Captain E. Prehn) is due to arrive at Port Said next Mon- day en route for China and Japan. She has a full first and second olass passenger list, including reliefs for the German squadron in the Far East. The Prins Eitel Friedrich is from the yard of the Vulcan Shipbuilding and Engineer- ing Company, Stettin. Her principal dimen- sions are: Length 508ft., breadth s9ft., 9in., moulded depth 36ft. The.register tonnage is 8,131 tons, and the displacement at a draught of 26ft., is 15,300 tons. There are three steel decks extending the entire length of the ship, and a partial orlop deck, and above these are the promenade and the boat deck, making. six decks in all. Perhaps the most striking no- velty is the gymnasium, which contains what appears to be a'complete installation of appli: ances for hygienic exercises. All told the number of people the ship is capable of carry- ing amounts to 1,138.

div.head: MENA HOUSE FOUR-HORSE COACH. .
div.p: Cairo-residents will be glad to learn, that on Tuesday 'next the sound of the horn an- nouncing the start of the Mena House stage- coach, which has been suspended tor several years, will be heard again. The management of the hotel have. just brought. over from Europe a handsome new team, which is sure to be the delight of the many: who are fond of a pleasant drive, such as is afforded by the road leading to the Pyramids. The coach will rundaily, leaving Cook's Office. at 11.45. Calling at the .different first-class hotels, it. will leave, the Savoy Hotel at i2 and reach the Pyramids at 1, returning . from Mena at 4 p.m. 'The return fare is, only' 15 piastres and tickets must be got at Cook's Office

The whole coach can also be hired. for the day at P.T. 300, or at P.T. 500, if driven by.a gentleman or by a lady. On moonlight nighta the, charges for the coach are P.T. 500 and P.T. 750 respectively.
Mena House operis on November 1, and judging from the enquiries which, daily reach the hotel office, its opening is awaited im. patiently by the many friends of this. most popular resort.

div.head:
THE PHARMACY AGITATION
LAST NIGHTS MEETING
APPOINTMENT OF COMMISION
div.p: The geheral meeting of the Cairopharmacists was held at the Cercle Artistique last night at 9.30 o'clock. Dr. Kupper, vice president of the Cairo Committee of the Associated Pharmacists, was in the chair, supported by the hon. secre- 'tary,.Mr. Dirlik,. and Messrs. A. Mandofia, Montini, and Dinkler.

The chairman opened the proceedings by briefly.summing up the causes which had led to the meeting being called. He then read a telegram from Mr. MacGregor, president of the Alexandria Association of Pharmacists, wish ing the Cairo branch of the. Association a full and satisfactory meeting, and hoping for a speedy, decision.

The hon. secretary then read the correspond- ence exchanged between the committee and Sir Horace Pinching, of which he gave the substance. On hearing that regulations were being drawn up by the Sanitary Department with reference to the management. of pharma- cies,' the committee wrote to the Director- General asking him to favour them with a draft copy of these regulations before sending them to the Mixed Court of Appeal. The Director-General replied expressing hiscomplete readiness to do so .. But here, unfortunately, the matter ended. The. draft copy was not forwarded. The draft . regulations were sent to.the Court of Appeal, and the law, as it.now stands, was finally publistred. Many of the Cairo committee were absent at the time of its publi- cation, which.aroused considerable discussion in Alexandria, where a general, meeting was organised. The Cairo committee wrote to the Alexandria committee on the subject and promised to hold a general meeting as soon aa possible. The Alexandria committee replied mentioning their intention of calling a. genieral meeting and of forwarding a letter of protest against the regulations to the Sanitary Depart ment. The Cairo committee then replied, suggesting that, to have due weight, thef letter shouldbear the .wignatures of both committees. This letter, however, arrived at Alexandria top late, whereon the Cairo com- mittee wired regretting the isolated action of the Alexandria: committee and followed their wire: by a letter stating their intention, of sending delegates to ask for an interview with Sir H. Pinching and to beg for a delay of one. month in the apphication of the law. The Director General expressed his readiness-to meet the delegates. At the meeting he declared himself ready to safeguard the interests and to meet the wishes of the Cairo pharmacists as far as was possible, and informed them that he .proposed to suspend the operation of thelaw till the end of the year The hon. secretary testified to the kindness and con- ciliatory spirit shown by the Director-General during the interview, which lasted for an hour. The Cairo committee then inferined the Alex: andria committee of the rosnit of the inter- view and expressed a hope that no isolated. action would be attempted and thiat the two committees wogld stady with the utmost care' a matter that was of such importance to the profession as a whole.

The hon secretary then informod the meeting that they had now to select- a commnission of six members at whose deliberations Mr. Dinkler would be present without a-vote, ds representing the Sanitary Department. Ho (the hon. seoretary). assured them that the holders of diplomas and genuine pharmacists ran no risks from the regulations. Their severity was aimed, according to the Director-General, against the charlatan, who infested the pro- fession in Egypt, and the capitalists, who were not pharmacists but put pharmacies in the charge of unqualified men. As for the election of a commission, it had been suggested that each nation should be represented. With thia he totally disagreed. Six experienced phar- macists were required.

A little discussion followed, after which the chairman and the hon. secretary stated that the commission should draw. up a report on the regulations and submit the same to be discussed at a general mee ing. .It was then decided that the commission should print and circulate ite report ten days before the date fixed. for the general meeting, to enable .everyone to stndy the question in all its bearings.

After thanking the Press for ita support the chairman called on the meeting to flect a' commission, and the following were elected :- Dr. Kuppers (26 votes), Mr. Dirlik (20),"Mr. Adalr (1) (20), Mr. Montini (14), A. Montobra (11), Joanovitch (10). The latter, however, declined to sit, and as the next two candidates had 9 votes each, the meeting had to decide between thein, with the result that Mr. Kaiser was elected by 16.votes.

div.head: THE FAYOUM HOSTPITAL
div.p: A Medinet-ol-Fayoum correspondent writes :- The American Mission hospitakin this town is filling.a hitherto much-needed want. It, differs from the Government hospitals inssmuch as the patients onri be Trented by their own doctors, if they so wish iv. But in the. Govern- ment hospitals the doctors attached to the hospital are the. only ones .who can attend the patients. Dr. and Mrs. Askern, of the American: Mission, are -in. oharge, of the hospital, and their management ldaves nothing to be desired,

div.head:
THE HEDJAZ.
UNFOUNDED REPORTS.
div.p: Reports have been for some time current that this province is the scene of.unusual disturbance and bloodshed. We are assured by a highly competent authority that there is nothing unusual in its condition. It remains, as ever, the theatre of every species of confliet, inter-tribal battles, rebellions against the central authority, highway robbery, and private feuds; but there is no reason to believe, that any of the parties concerned are displaying more than their usual activity.

div.head: THE ROBBERS OF EL-ARISH.
div.p: Several of our contemporaries have recently. published a statement to the effect that a band of brigands infested the caravan ronte between Kantara and -El Arish, and not content with robbing travellers, had repulsed a Ccast Guard patrol which attempted to arrest them by a heavy and well-directed fire.

On enquiry at the Ministry of the Interior we find that on August 2 and August 16 certain Bedouin tribesmen stole a few camels which were the property of another tribe, or another section of their tribe. A council .of sheikhs and elders was called to enquire into the matter, No lives were lost, no caravans attacked,andno Coast Guards repulsed. Hadany real encounter taken place we should doubt- less have heard most astonishing stories of slaughter and revolt.

div.head: THE PLAGUE.
div.p: Egypt.is entirely free of, bubonic plague, with the exeeption of a case under treatment at Port Said, which was wrongly announced as having ended fatally on the 19th inst.
The last patient at Alexandria- was dis- charged as cured yesterday.
The quarantine measures on the departure of vessels have been suppressed since Sunday.

div.head: FAYOUM IRRIGATION.
div.p: Our Medinet el-Fayoum Correspondent writes :- I am glad to state that there are no more complaints from the villagers about irrigation, and. the water is being distributed equitably. The Sub-Inspector of the Fourth Circle, Mr. Tottenham, has left .the Fayoum for Beni-Souef in order to inspect the works there. So far he has not sent in his report on his recent visit to the Wady Rayan. I under- stand that he agrees with Sir William Garstin in regard to the Rayan reservoir.
Mr. Clowes is expected back from leave at the end of this month.

div.head: MIXED APPEAL COURT.
div.p: This morning, at the sittings of the Mixed Appeal Court, two criminal cases and 79 civil- and commercial cases were called, The hearing of these cases las been postponed to future dates or else they have been transferred to the special- causelist.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA BLIND SCHOOL
div.p: In her annual report on the Ministering Children's League, the Countess :of .Meath says :- +

Out work thr the blind in .Rgypt .continues to be most encouraging. The M.C.L. Industrial School in Alexandria, is being suocensfully carried on under the management of'sn efficient local committee. : Last year, when I. visited Egypt, it was a pleasure to find that A whole honse, instead of a few rooms, had been rented for the purpose of giving instruction to sightless men and boys, The house proved most usefal: for. the ,wndertaking, and it was felt desirable to seoure it for a permanenay. During my visit to Alexandris this spring overtures were made to the landlord with a view to buying the house, but he would not come to terms with the committee. Mr. Alderson, the owner of a great deal of land in the city, was next approached, and, in the most generous manner possible, he kindly presented us with a piece of land in a central position in . Alexandria, as he, as s practical business man, highly approved of the exoellent work (securing ready purchase). done by the blind. This gift of land is the more gratifying as the valve of. house property is rising very rapidly-in Alexandria, and prohibitive prioes are being asked for it. The site for the school presented .by Mr. Alderson was added to by another donor, but that, contributed by the former alone is worth £900, and; besides this, he most generously gave a handsome donation towards the building fund. Nor is this all, for Mr. Alderson took nearly the whole charge and. expense of making arrangements for the ceremony. of laying the foundation stone of the new. building, and he is now superintending the erection of this new institution. Mr. Alderson's gift to our League. is a most valu- able ong, and, as far.as I'know, it is the largest we have ever received from any person not connected with the soeiety. I trust that, as an association, we are not ungrateful to our bene- factors, and I feel' sure that we shall wish by- and-bye to express our gratitude for so generous a gift by passing an unanimous vote of thanka to Mr. Alderson.

div.p: Ia Délégution Manicipalo, c'ont rdanie le s ootobre 1904 à-4 h: p.m. sous li preidencs de M. Amb. A. RAlli.

Please address all orders for tickets to the Banking Firm "El Nassib," General Agents of the Royal Hungariam Lottery, Alexandria, Rue Tewfik No.12. All information concerning the lottery is given free of charge, either verbally or by writing.
For the due execution of order, we respectfully ask our clients to let us have their orders by first mail accompanied by the remittance for tickets.
The drawings will be held publicly, in the presence of the Delegates of the State, of two Royal notaries, and of the Direction of the Lottery.

The absolutley protect the interests of the public the Hungarian Ministry of Finances has created a special Department charged with the mission of overseeing the movements of the Lottery. Moreover the HUNGARIN STATE guarantess the payemnt in the species of all the winning numbers.

div.head: GREAT EXODUS FROM SPAIN
div.p: The exodus of emigrants from Spain has assumed such proportionk.that the municipal couneils of Madrid,: Valencia,. and Vigo have decided to address the Government on the subjeet. It is pointed. out that thousands of acres of land are going out of cultivation owing to the emigration of labourers, and there is also s serious loss being cansed. to the country by the departure of skilled artisans. Hardly a ship leaves a Spanish port which does not carry a large number of emigrants, who, are making their way chietly to the Central and South American States.

div.head: THE UNPARDONABLE SIN
div.p: Salem,. New Jersey, is Eghast because a pri- vate of the State's Hospital Corps has married an Ameriean negress who nursed liim through yellow fever: His superiors (says tlee Tele- graph's' correspondent) demand his resignation; bnt the private defies their ultimatum, quoting the article of the Constitution declaring all persons. free and eqnal.

div.head: A SCOTCH GRAND VIZIER
div.p: T P's Weekly quotes the following story from "Dr. Anderden's "Bee" in' illustration of the ubiquity and versatility of Seotsmen. "In. the year 1739," says the doctor, "the Russians and Turks, weary of war, commissioned two plenipotentiaries-on the Russian side Marshal- General Keith, on the side of the Turks the Grand Vizier of the Sultan-to make peace. The two diplomatists met, and carried on protracted negotiation through interpreters. When all at last was satisfactorily settled the plentpotentiaries rose: to take formal leave of each other-the Marshal waking his bow with his liat in his hand, and the Grand Vizier his salaam with his turban on his head. .These ceremonies of leavetaking over, the Grand Vizier suddenly straightened himpelf, and, to .the Marshal's utter amszement, marched np to him, gripped him affectionately by the hand, and, in the very broadest Sootch atcent, cried, Dinna,be sarprised, mon ; I'mzo' the same country wi' yoursel'. Weel'I mind seeing yon and your brither, when boys, passing by to the schoof at Kirkealdy,' Why, who-who are yon f gasped. the Mershal, staggering back in his bewilderment. "I am Grand Vizier to the >Sultan of Turkey, but .. my father was bellman o' Kirkcaldy !"

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY
div.p: Lieutenant. H. L. Mackwotth, D.S.O., Royal Engineers, doing duty at Aldershot, has been selected for service with the Khedive's army. Mr. Mackwotth has beld a commnission for six and a-half years. He went throngh the South African campaign 1899-02, including the relief of Kimberley and the. campaign iu Orangia and the Transvaal (mentioned in despatches, D.S.O., medals with, clasps). He was lately employed in Somaliland,. Brevet-Major Frauk B. Pearce, C.M.G., Westi Yorkshire Regiment, Deputy Commissioner for Central Affica. Protectorate, has just been pro- moted to substantive rank after over eightees years' service, the greater part of the last five of which-has been spent in Ceutral Afriea. He served under the West Yorks in Sir Francis Scott's Ashanti Expedition 1895-96 (star) and in 1898 saw active service ain .Central Africa with the Southern Angoniland Expedition (medal with elasp). The following year he snc cesafully commanded the espedition against Kwamba, his services being recognised by,a well-deserved brevet-majbrity, and he further added to his active service experience. with the West Yorks in the late Boer war, 1900 (medal with clasp). The Companionship of the Order of St. Michael and St. George was recently conferred on him, as a further recognition of his services in Central Africa, by his Majesty.

The Assaye will leave. Southampton the Joth November for. Bombay with about 1,060 troops on board for yarious regiments, com- panies, batteries, anel battalions in India. The liner will reach Bombay on the 8th December. A week later she will make the return voyage with time-expired men and details, reaching Southampton on the 6th January.
Second-Lieutenant, A. J. Loftus, 1st Bat- talion Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, has been granted leave of absence until the 17th No vember, pending embarkation for Egypt."

The first-class battleship Irresistible (Captain G .. H. Henderson) will leave Malta on Novem- ber 11, and calling at Plymouth on" the 20th, will proceed to Chatham, where she will pay off on November.30, and be recommissioned on the following day for service on the Medi. terranean Station. She will leave Chatham on December 3, and is timed to. reach Gibraltar five days later. Abont £4,900 will be expended on the Irresistible in refitting at Malta.

div.head: IS THE ENGLISH NOVEL DEAD?
div.p: Mr. G. S. Street's article lamenting the deca- dence of the English novel is dealt with in the October number of, the Pall . Mall Magazine. in a symposium, to which wations- eminent hands contribute. Let us quote from "John. Olfver Hobbes" "The quality," she says, "which seens fa- tally absent in much modern English fiction is knowledge, and the few 'authors who write of what they know address a vast army of readers who have never been trained to form any opinion of sound work, It, is uneeasonable to expect a supreme genius in every composer or successful but ephemeral light reading. The number of great novel writers is small-far, far smaller than the number of great painters and. creative musicians. .A deep experience of the world and human beings is given to few- because few can bear the suffering which is its price, and fewer' still .have the moral: courage to tell the truth .. It is quite certain that there can be no vital drawing of modern English life while it remains the fashion in this country to describe women as they never were, and men as they cannot be. Thac- keray in his day uttered the same complaint. He dared pot speak out, and he handed on the jarketable false sentiment with such sin- cerity in his satire that he was never 'populer.' The least intelligent reader always. felt that Thackeray knew him through and through. Pretty passages were all very' well, bnt the truth pierced them as the string runs visibly through a necklace of glass beads. ' When a modern novelist wishes to be daring he draws some abnormal woman, enflowed with all the worst qualities of his own sex. She is a deca dent and effeminate Tom Jones-Jones' with- out vigotir, withont and heart, and withont a single excuse. for his animalism ; Jones in a scented tea-gown and a female's wig; Jones reeling off D'Annunzio in - słoppy English ; Jones sobbing out Ibsen in the vernacular of the omnibus ; Jones no longer drunk with wine, but mad with hysteria.'

div.head: LORD ANGLESEY ON HIMSELF IN T WEEDS
div.p: The Marquess of Anglesey's occupations at Dinard, where che is recruiting his health, are driving and poker-work. . "I, must apologise,", he said to aMail interviewer; "for not appearing before you in peacock-blue plush, wearing a diamtond , and. sapphire tiara, a turquoise dog-collar, ropes of pearls and slippors studded with Burmprubies; but I prefer, andalways have preferred, Scotch. tweedl." .. "I'm writing a book-on myself," he added. "It will probably consist. of a series of essays on humanityas and have known it. I may have somnething to. say about some of my friends, I don't think I shall act again just yet. I've had the usual:offer from America, but my health wouldn't stand it. Just to amuse myself I'm adapting plays. When things get right again- in two or three years from now -- I shall have my own theatre once more." :

div.head: NOTES UPON GREEK AND LATIN PAPYRI
div.p: In the second volmye giving specimens of papyri in the possession of Lord Amherst, there are two fragmnents of elassic anthors which merit notice. One of them, which unfortunately only contains-15 legible lines, gives part of a tragedy. Thie scene of which they are descrip- tive eyidently took place at Troy during the celebrated siege. The speakers are certainly Hector and Polydamas. The passage preserved does- not. offer to literature any specially poetic expression, con- seqnently our chief practical interest in it will afise from ascertainiug, if . possible, of which poet's werk it affords an example, We can hardly err. if with Weil and Radermacher we assign it to the lost tragedy of "Hector" by. Astydainas, who, we are told by Pfutarch, by this play gained a victory famous in the dra- tnatic annals of Athens. The other fragment presents only five lines that can be satisfactorily completed ; but they tell us sufficient to detect it to be a passage from the argument of the "Skiron" of Euripides,. because one of these lines. is quoted as being from that work in the. "Florilegeum" of Stobeaus. The collection of papyri at Strasburg -pos- sesses part of a prologue to a Greek comedy, that has been edited by . Kaibel and Reitzen- stein, which indicates a most interesting story, but no scholar has hitherto been able to divine the name of the work, or its author. .After a fey badly preserved sentences, uttered by some deity, the prologue proceeds. to tell us that once upon a time two twin brothers, Sosthenes and Detnea, married two twin sisters, who bore to one.a son, to the other a daughter. The brothers for some reason went to Asia and there encountered great dangers and advent- ures, one was imprisoned and assisted to escape by the other, who in his turn was incarcerated for aiding the first to get away. They remain; ed absent 16 years ; doubtless the liberated one declining to go home until he in turn could rescue his brother. Though wethave no more of the epitome of the comedy it is very .easy to foresee that during the 16 years the boy and girl have grown up and douhtless become enamoured of each other, and probably are in some difficulty which only the return of. their respective parents will solve. No title of any recorded play, or suminary of the plot of a lost comedy, appears to apply to this fragment. It is to be hoped that one or more of the lines we now possess may be found quoted by some scholiast, or. lexicographer, with a note as to their author. One of the longest of the newly recovered portions of poems by an unknown author found in Egypt is the fragment of an Epic of Ninos published by Herr Wilcken and M. Weil. It relates to Ninos, the celebrated builder of Nineveh, hia mother, whose name is herein given us as Thambe, his aunt Derkeia, and her daughter, whose name does not transpire from the fragment, but undoubtedly was Semiramis, because Derkeia er Derke was stated by classic writers, previously known,. to have been her mother's nane. The portion of the poem we now forfunately can peruse commences with a conversation, between Ninos and. Derkeia, in which he craves the lady's'permission to espouse her daughter. Claining that his age, of 17, is that. preferable for marriage, and also that her own was also just suitable, (though he politely does not give. hers it appears from.his arguments to have been 14), he urges his suit. The intended mother-in law. desired the nuptials. to. be postponed for two years, but Ninos points out. that he may be slain in warfare and should prepare an heir, for as both the young people were only offspring, otherwise the direct royal line would lapse. The second part of the text contains the arguments. of the young lady. to her aunt Thambe. These are not so much of an oratorical order'as to be convincing, but her tears and- sighs appear to have gained her cause. :The two aunts enter into conversation as to obtain- ing the king's permission. The narrative is then broken off by a mutilation of the papyrus and.when it recommences we find the young people united, and Ninos proceeding to some war, and an account of the campaign in a mountainous country follows. The combats are' in Armenia, and Ninos is asdisted by Greek and Carian mercenaries. The army is accom- parried by a hundred, or more, elephants. This fragment of the text terminates with A description of the line of battle srranged by Ninos. Itis plain that the plot, or interest, of the story centred in the enforced separation of the newly-matried prince and princess, especially the proloriged "campaign of Ninos. Com- pensatory comfort must have been derived by the bride arising from the evidence afforded, by the test of war, of the military genius of Ninos. It is indeed wonderful, resembling thecelebrated exploits of-Cyrus in the "Cyropedia." Generally in these stories the ancient novelists, or quasi historians, separated the loveri by some violent peril, or abduction, but here the cause appears to have .been merely the warrior duty of a martial prince and to have been .virtually voluntary. Dr. Carl Sehmidt has at length completely published all the Coptic version of the Apo- chryphal "Acts of Panl" which was acquired. by the Heidelburg Library in Egypt some years ago. The text he has -been enabled to print presents some 2,600 verses; which must be about three-fourths of the whole work because the stichometrical analysis of early .Christian books preserved in the Codex Claromontanus tells us it possessed a total of 3,560 verses. The new Coptic text, however, does not afford us so much fresh matter because it appears that "the complete ."Acte of Paul" inoluded three works already known, and extant. These. are the "Acts of Paul and Thecla," the short tract entitled."The Martyrum Pauli," and the "Correspondence of Paul with the Corinthians." Moreover, the book appears to have little historical value. The parts that are novel relate to alleged occurrences at Antioch, Myra. Sidon, Tyre, Philippi, and Rome. The events at the latter Metropolis concern the persecu- tion under Nero, and it is an interesting fact to be noted by ecctesiastical scholars that there is no mention of the presence of the Apostle Peter at Rome, in the Coptic, but the text,is in a very fragmentary condition. About the same date . Mrs. Agnes Smith Lewis has published the work found by her in a convent in the Nitrian desert a, few years ago : "The Mythological Acts of the Apostles." They are of a decidedly apochryphal character, and useless for historical purposes. A curious incident relates to the burial of aryoung girl in the foundation of a bathhouse that was being erected. This cruel form' of propitiating the earth demon will be familiar to the students of the early history of mankind, and may be found fully.referred to in M. Lefebure's work on Egyptian Rites connected with edifices. A Neo-Greek poem has recently been edited in. the "Revue de l'Histoire des Religions" relating the sacrificial murder of the wife of the architect of the bridge over the river Arto, in European Turkey, erected in she middle ages-

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
div.p: We do not hold ourmives responsibie for the opinions expressed 'by our correnpondante, but we winh, in a spirit of fait play to all, to.permit - within certain necewary limita- free discusnion.

div.head: REDUCTION OF GARRISON
div.p: Sir,-The excellent leading article in yester- day's issue, and the action of the Alexandria branch of the British Chamber of Commerce in Egyptin declining to join that of Cairo in protesting against the reduction of the British Garrison, will effectually scotch the ridiculous agitation against the reduction. Anything more sense- less and ill-timed it is impossible to imagine. If there had been any real prospective danger one would have expected the . other foreign "colonies" to have taken the matter up by holding public meetings and making, repre- sentations to their respective consuls ; but aa far as is known no action has been taken or is contemplated in this direction. Take the Greek for instance-the 'largest of the colonies. Are not their lives and property as dear to the Greek community as ours are to us, and are they not as capable as we are of gauging unto- ward eventualities-they who have settled in this country for centuries longer-than we have and, by reason of their closer connection with the native population, possess, one would think, far better opportunities than. we do of estimating the possibilities of civil commotion which may follow upon the step about to be taken ? And yet they show not the remotest sign of apprehonsion whatsoever. Is it not then astounding that the .complaint should originate with the Britishers alone ? I cannot but think that the . movement-if it deserves to be dignitied by such a name-is confined to a small and uninfluential section of our community-perliaps even to. a mere handful of busybodies who hope to gain a cheap popularity. I am, etc.,

div.head: EGYPT AND THE AGREEMENT
div.p: To THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE. Sir,-I have read with much interest your leading article commenting upon my letter of the 20th inst. relative to the above subject. You will remember that the Anglo-French Agreement was submitted to and sanctioned by the British Parliament. I was not in the House at the time, but from the reports I read I have a distinct recollection that it was stated from the Treasury Bench that the Agreement awaited. ratification by the French Chambers. I'am quite unable to say whether such a course is essential or optional according to the French Parliamentary Law, but, unless my memory has played me false, I would submit that my trictures are warrantable. I am, and c.,

div.head: THE GHIZEH ZOO
div.p: TO THS EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE. Sir,-I have just been reading, by way .of Auch innocent distraction as is permissible on the "Sawbath," the reply of "A Cairo Corres- pondent" to my letter on the Ghizeh "Zoo" which appeared in your issue of the 15th inst. "A Cairo Correspondent" has, to say the least of it, a suspicious method of apologizing for its delinquencies ; for mark how he meets my complaints. It is, forsooth, not the authori- ties but I who am at fault. It is I who stand convicted upon my own confession of the serious offence of inspecting the Go- vernment stores.It is I, likewise, who am guilty of the still more heinous crime of bribing an official with two piastres to give me a morsel of bread and one or two dates which "A Cairo Correspondent" alleges were part and parcel of such Government stores as aforesaid. Verily this is a formidable indietment. But is it, I would meekly inquire, to such shifts that "A Cairo Correspondent" must resort in order to excuse official negligence or something: worse ! He might as reasonably have charged me with Die majeste whilst he was about-it. However, if "A Cairo Correspondent" is genuinely in- earn-Cairo, October 23. est, let him bring me before the competent tri- bunal, and, to enable him to do so, I now and hereby authorise you, Sir, to communicate to him my name and address so that justice may be done and the law of the land vindicated ! I am, etc., -

div.head: SCOTS KIRK DISPUTE.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE .; Sir, - Referring to your remark on this sub- ject in your paper of to-day, it neems to me to be a "peety" that Sandy should "give up his releegion and jine the Epeescopalians.". Would it not be better of him . (without giving up his"releegion") to join the "Society of Friends?" It is needless to point out the many advantages he would thus gain,-and no doubt appreciate. I am, e .;

div.head: A FORTUNE TO BE WON
div.p: By the foundation of the Bank "El Nassib" in Alexandria, of which we have already written in a preceding number, Egypt also receives a General Agency of the Royal Hungarian Lottery. . This great lottery in. a few years bns acquired the full confidence and sym- pathy of the world. We think it will interest our readers if we give to-day a' description of the nature of thia Lottery. The Royal Hungarian Lottery is no private enterprise but an. institution established by the Royal Hungarian Government, and the board of this Government guarantees the punctual payment of all the numerous win nings. This institution therefore offers abso- lute socurity and deserves the -entire confi- dence of the public. Under these circumstances it cannot surprise anyone that this Lottery, which has been in existence only a short time (it was establislied 8 years ago), has conquered the world. As in Egypt the number of customers of the Royal Hungarian Lottery is very large, this General-Agency ("Bank El Nhssib") was. established in this town at Rue Tewfik No. 12, to afford those interasted in this country every fncility and 'ease in the purchase of tickets without any delay, to assure them of the emphatie maintenance of their interesta in every way, and further,/to pay the, winnings promptly. All those who are already in connexion with this Royal Hungarian Dottery but want any explanations, or those who wish to purchase tickets, may direct their enquiries to the General Agency "El Nassib" in Alexandria, No. 12, Rue Tewfik, verbally or by letter. All requeeta will. be settled promptly and without any fee. There are issned 110,000 tickets, of which 55,000, that js the half, must win undoubted- ly .. These 55,000 tickets naturally cannot be drawu in one single drawing. Therefore, and for reasons which are indicated later, each Lottery is divided into 6 parts, named classes,whose drawings take place at intervals of 8-4 weeks. The big prizes of these 6 classes are as. follows :. Ist Class Crówns 60,000; -- 2nd .3rd 4th 5th 6th 200,000, 100,000, 80,000, 60,000, 50,000, etc.,etc. One crown equals frs. 1.05 .- Withonesingleticket it is possible.to win One Million Crowns, as according to the destina- tions of the Official Prospectus the premium of crowns 600,000, will go . to that number which draws the last prize between 400,000 and 2,000crowns. If this prize drawn at last the prize of drowns 400,000, so the fortunate possessor of this ticket will become millionaire. By the following copy of the balance of the Official. Prospectus it will be seon that the total receipta are to :be employed for the prites. 11 70,000. - 80,000. - 90,000. - 100,000. - 600,000, -400,000. claie BALANCE-SHEET. tiotrete Orowna 16,80,000 prisce ... 3000 3000 4000 000 55000 Prises. However, in consideration of the enormoas cost of organization, managoment and control, there will be deducted 20% of the value of the winnings, aocording to the Official Prospectus. .. The smallest gain in the 6th olass covers the total of the stakes of all the 6 classes, for the smallest prize in the 6th olass is Crowns 200 ; deduet 20% and there. remains crowns 160. The player only winning such a small prize recovers his whole disbursement. Really, the most important loss could only be crowns 160,, or frs. 168, paid for a whole ticket. On the other hand, the fortunate winner may be happy all his life, because there is a' large number of. very considerabie prizes. The price.of the tickets for all the 6 alasses of one Lottery is fixed by the board of govern- ment at crowns 160, or. frs. 168. The General Agency, "El Nassib," sells the ticketa at this price without any extra charge. The system of classes was also ohosen on the supposition that a number of partakers would not like to pay the amount' of frs. 168 all at onoe. Thererore the Lottery waa divided into classes, so that it is pomeible to pay the atakee proportionally to the olases. The stakes for each class are for one whole ticket :- Ist.class Crowns 12: or frs.18.60 2nd 3rd 4th 5th 6th .Total Crowns 160. or frs. 168 .-- To facilitate play to people who are not willing to pay the prios of one whole tieket there is issued a certain nunias of tio divided into }, 3, and i parts. Therefore, who : will not risk fra. 168, can play for a' smaller amount. The sums to be won with such a participation are already big enough, becaure the Lottery's winnings are extrsordinarily high. The tickets are numbered from 1 to 110,000 aud the |, f and i have for distinetion, the letters A, B, C, D, etc. Should a partaker lose his ticket, his right of participation will be guarded, according to the Offeial Pionreotus, if he advisesethis faotito the Geneaal Agosey "El Nassib,",Alexandria, No. 12, Rue Tewfk. In general manner, we. have given an explanation of the srrangement of this Royal: Hungarian Lottery, which appears compliosted at firat, but is really very simple, .Moreover, to-day's imsue contains a very complete explanation in the advertimeaiunt of the General-Agonoy . div.head: EGYPTIAN MINING ACTIVITY.
div.p: In view of the existing activity in Egyptian Mining, the Directors of the London and Paris Exchange have retained the services of a competent Mining Engineer, whose reports on the present position of the various properties is of the utmost importance. This Information is at the disposal of Clients. Correspondents contemplating Investment in Egyptian Mining Enterprises would be well advised in communicating with the Exchange before doing so, and thus avoid the loss of capital incurred by the purchase of worthless securities.
The London and Paris Exchange undertake the purchase or sale of all classes of Mining Securities on the London Stock Exchange and Continental Sources.

div.head: LA MORT DU SULTAN MOURAD
div.p: Apres la mort- des Sultans, leurs dé pouilies mortellen doivent étre transportées au vieuz semil de Tep-Capou pour y être lavéen, d'apres l'assge de la Cour. Il en est de meme pour tous lea prinoen et les -membres de, la famille royate. Le Sultan Hamid retase l'autorisation de laver le corps de son frere au Palais de Top-Capou, il n's même pas permis qu'on le kevât dans ss résidenee du Palais de Toheragon, où, il %tait mort. Bon cereueil a éte mis dans une mouche a vapeur, et debarqae sar les qaais de la douanede Stamboul, cù le corps a été lavé daps ane des pidocs de la douane. Apres quoi le oorpe a ét6 remis dans le cereueil, sous la surveillance du Préfet de Police, du Gouveroear de In ville, de Teherkes Meh- mat Paobs et de Fehim Pachs. Il s éte place dans le tombesu de si mere dans la mosquee de Yeni-Djami. L'enterrement a ed lieu sane le moindre cérémonial ; on évité de faire passer le convoi fanebre psr les grandes rues, on s'est engagé duns, les mellen len plus étroites, et: jasqne dans des impasses, quitte à rebroasser ebemin pla- sieurs fois. Tous ceux qai voulaient le sui- vre etsient 6cartes. Len personnes qui ont témoigne lear douleur ou leur sympathie de laçon trop évidente ont été. de suite arresées et inearcérées.Des sentaines de per- ponnes one été exilées, parmi lerqaelles il y a un.général. Le nomore des espions avait été sonsidérablement sugmenté, leur prin- cipale ocoupstion consistait à recherober. ceaz qui feraiens la moindre allasion à le mort de Mourad. C'est un usage consscré de temps immemorial, et inserit comme tel dans les regintres de déods da Palais, et de eeuz de la. 8. Porte, que les depouille mortelles des Sultans doivent sortir par la grande porte da Palais de Top-Capou. De sercneil est porté à bras su mauisolée. fiebement orne d'etoffes précieuses, suivi de tous les Ministres, du Grand Vizir, dew bauta fonetionsires, du Cheikh-ul-Ielam, du Corpe des Ulémas, da Ministre de la Guerze, des maréchsuz, des généraus, des colonels, ep passans au milieu d'pne haie de soldets syaot les fasile bayonnettes à terre. Non seulement oes honneurs n'ont pas ete rendus a Mourad, mais le soir du meme jour etant l'anniversaire de son mdnement sa Trone, Hamid n'ep a pud moins fait illuminer toute la ville de Stam- boal. Il est vrai que chez len tures on n'obeervepee le deuil comme chez nous, par ls marque extériegre dels couleur noire; ce- pendant, ches euz sdsii, même le bas peuple Lemoigne as doalenr et son respect pour ls mori des siens en reinettant a ane.epoque 6loignee toutes fetes oa touterrreanions d'amie: Bien souvent des Sultann ont été égorges et mis en pie:es par la populace et les Clemas, à csuse de leur tyrannie. Ce- pendant leuzs restes mortels etnient con- daite à lear dornière. demeure avec toute Is pompe et tous les honneurs das a an Saltan, par cette meme population qui l'avsit swsminé. Hamid par as conduite a done Iaime bien loin derriere lui, cette populace par le manière avee laquelle il a agi vis-a-vio. de sou frere, qui ne, lai avait fait ancan mal. On. eroysit qu'spres la mort du Sul- tan Moarad, ses femmes et tous le membres de ss famille, oissersient d'etre l'objet des mesures severes de surveil lance. Melheureusement, il parais, d'a pies les derniarer nouvelles de Constsn tinople, que le nombre des zapties, des gen darmes et des espions vient d'étre sugmenté avee ordre de sarveiiler jasqa'sax moindre mouvemenis de ss famille.

Près de 1000 titres ont été échangés.

div.head: OUR PARIS LETTER
div.p: Paris is at its best, or, rather, if one may be permitted po to express oneself, at one of its best, at the, present moment. I have just returned from long and wearisome travel, and I feel the calm antumnal repose of this most heautiful'of cities, as I can imagine that every foreiguer who, arriving at the time of the "Ete de Saint Martin," and remaining long enough to be at his ease, must feel it. Generally one is back before this time, and for this reason the sensation is an unnsual one to and Parisian. .

The French Chambers' will have no lack .of work to get through during the Session which opeied yesterday. To impose the principle of income tax on a nation which has never en- joyed that form of fiscal felicity, to pass a measure of working.class insurance, to ratify a treaty . with England which may prove_a turning-point in the world's . history, and, incidentally, : to effect a separation between Church and State-all, that' is surely enough legislative pabulum .for the most hungry of parlismentarians to absorb. But everybody must see that-even. without reckoning with the chapter of sccidents-the strongest Govern- ment in the world might well come to grief over one or another of the subjects just enumerated .. Now, although the "Bloc". is- still apparently, solid enough, not s few of its members are said to be just a little tired of M. Combes, and would. like to see somebody else in his place. , M. Combes, however, is not an easy man to get rid of, as he has proved by this.time. I should not be surprised if he held his own through it all. Threatened men live long-in polities as elsewhere.

M. Waldeck-Roussean is, unfortunately for his-country, no more; nevertheless, defunctus adhuc loquitur. His posthumous papers prove, beyond question, that he never intended the Associations law to be used for the purpose of destroying the Religious Oyders in France, but to regularise their position by subjeeting them to State control. In s country: where government is nothing if not highly centralised, and. where the State' aims at being, and thostly is, omnipotent in practice as well as in theory, that was a legitimate object. Unfortunately, the author of the measure was ahtisfied with having formulated. his policy, and left it to another to carry out. In so doing he committed a grave impradence. His stccessor, as the event has shown, was not the man for the job. Whether M. Combes really meanit to administer the law honestly, in the ight of these papers. The late Premier lacked, oresight; the present Premier lacked either byalty'to his predecessor or power to control is party.

A pathetic scene was witnessed a few days go on the platform of. the Abbeville station. A number of, nuns, who had devoted their ives to the education of the young girls in-the own; had been expelled from their convent, nd journeyed to the statiog en route for their lace of exile.The one who attracted most ttention was Sister Saint Jean Baptiste, the perior of the convent, who is over eighty ears of age. When theaged lady saw the train nd the locomotiye, she burstinto tears. She had entered theconventof Abbeville in 1845; andhad hever left it until she was compelled to do so; onseqnently she was completely ignorant of what w. railway was like. Her |first railway jourey was to a place of exile.

An incident at Brest reveals the extraordin -. ary state of things prevajling in the French arsenals. A week ago some clerks and work- men employed in the dockyard made use, at a public meeting, of insulting expressions towards their own'officers. Che of the orstors declated that the officers of the French fleet were only good for running shipe asbore. Vice-Admiral Mallarme, commanding the port, invited the officials of the men's union to wait upon him with a view to an explanation and retractation of this language. Confronted with the Admiral, the speakers. absolutely refused to withdraw any one of their expressions, . which were as insulting against the Government as against the etat-major of the deckyard. The position, therefore, is this :- Government servants in Government pay taaduce their own superiors and insist on their right te criticise as private citizens. The piqaaney of the situation is added to by a despatch which M. Pelletan is said. to have sent to the Admiral, calling the attention of the workmen to their duties towards the Administration. The Minister,is, perhaps, not unmindful of the fact that Parliament has reassembled on Tuesday and that some account may be required of his stewardship.

Despite the efforts of. the: Liquidator appointed' by the Frenoh .Government. who claimed the right to seize the Trade Mark and Iabel of the Grande Chartreuse, the monk have made arrangements. for continuing the manufacture of their liqueurs in the North of Spain. These will now be shipped -to England under the label "Liqueur Fabriquee Tarragone par les Peres Chartreux." It is the only one, they.claim, identically the same ai that made at the Monastery of the Grande Chartrense in Franoe previous to the ex pulsion of the monks, who have, kept intact the secret of its manufacture. As the old Inbel of the Grande Chartreuse is registered in Englapd'as a Trade Mark, the property of the Abbe B."Bey, anyone, except the agents of. the mmonka, selling a liqueur in the country under that label, will make himself liable to penalties Yor infringement.

In that sacrediregion where the fanhions are crented they have no time, to consider the weathers or, rather, it is considered as a mere, maiter of busineRs. Brains are being racked for winter styles. Keen and unscrupulous foreign competition has mnade the Paris "cou- turier" very shy of exposing his secrets before their time. It requires a workl of ingennity, nowadays, to obtain an inkling of the coming mode. The greatest sinners in . pirating the Paris fashions are Germany and America. But in comparison with Berlin, New York. is but mildly harmful to the Rue de la Paix. Kaiser- stadt is at the very doors of- Paris, whereas New York is always fifteen days sway, counting the out and home journey. It is easy for the German dressmaker to buy a model at the moment of it publication, paying perhaps three or four thousand francs Xthe price is of little consequence to her), hasten with. the ipoil to Berlin, and have it reproduced; in any quantity. The same dress that is marked #120 in the home of Paris, "coutute" is sold at one-third the figure in the German capital. The dress is a Paris dress in all essentials, and skilled workers can be found on the banks of the Spree as they. tan on the banks of the. Seine: Who can resist such competition ? Even some Parisiennes, who pique themselves on their perfect taste, are not immine from such temptation. Thus dresses . designed in Paris but made in Germany are to berfound on the backs of fair inhabitants of .the "ville. lumiere." It is all very well to sppeal to- patriotism, but the argument of the purse is stronger than any.

Whilst "the ouvriere" is justly 'celebrated for her natural taste and her aptitude for ar. tistic arrangement, the real superiority of Paris, and that which can never be taken from her, consista in the creation of the seasotr's style. Let the creator be. removed to London or New York, and she quickly loses her gift. The atmosphere of Paris supplies the neces- sary stimulus( and you cannot export atmo- sphere. In the great houses whose signathre on the dresses is the wearer's certificate of ele- gance, the most important person is the dresn- designer. A salary of 2,000 frs. (£80) a month is, not unoonimonly, the renumeration of these gifted creatures. A foreign or provincial lady enters. the salon of a great dressmaker with. much the feelings of a patient consulting a spe- cinlist. She is certain that all is not right with her, but she cannot define her complaint. With the eye of a great artist the creator of the fashions sums up her "pointe." "Madame wishes a robe for an evening reception or k marringe 1' ."Very well." Instantly the pencil goes to work, and in the space of five minutes there is s perfectsketch upon paperof the dress that Madame pught to wear on the occasion. Not only. is she a perfect artist, this "arbiter elegaritiarum," but she has, the tact of a diplo- mat as well as the grace and carriage of a uchess. Under colour of giving hints on dress, he conveys little lessons in deportment; but it is so delicately done, that there is none to take offenge. Madame should not hold her robe so : ca frtigue la main." It does nothing of the sort, but it is a delicate way of saying the "cliente" has not quite got the art of holding her dress. "The dress would be better if madame held her arms to her side"-another hint that the body is not perfect in ite pose. A few days pass, and at the end of that time "l'etrangere" has been completely metamor- phoned-the provincial chrysalis has become a Parisian batterfly, and, onde more Paris has asserted her sapremacy.

"Change here for . the Opera. " That will presently' be the cry heard in the subterranean passages of the Metropolitain. The station under the Opera, constituting one of the most interesting pieces of railway en- gineering on record, will be opened to the public in a few days. The work has taken little more than a year, and has been accomplished with remarkable speer, Below ground -is an astonishing structure as: large as the Arc de Triomphe, and 'probably more massive. It carries three railway lines! one coming directly from the Palais Royal and following the line of the Avenue de l'Opera ; the others in touch with the stations of the Boisand" the . outer Boulevards. In order not to disturb the stabili- ty of the masonry, the lines:do not cross one another, buttraverse the great arch atadiffer- ent angles. The characteristic- sign of the Metropolitain stations -two artistic, arms. in wrought metal stretching .before the entrance to the stairway are wanting, from. the-Place de l'Opera: Such an erection would have done damage to the perspective of, perhaps, the noblest thoroughfare in Europe, and would have consorted ill with the masterpiece of Gar- nier behind it. Consequently, a graoeful mat- ble balustrade has been. constructed, reaching to the waist of a man, and forming the fringe to the "tron."

To many people it is unfortunate that the Place de l'Opera and, more epecially, the broad expanse of pavement before the Opera House itself, should have been chosen ss the site of the stationi. It is in the very heart ot Paris and the rallying ground of vast assemb Inges on public fete-days. On Jniy 14 and at Mi Careme it is a seething mass of people. The entrance to the station, with its broad flight of stege descending directly into the bowels of the earth, might easily become a desth-trap in the case of a formidable crowd invading the Place. The balustrades would be of little avail against the pressure of a thousand people This is the serious objection to the position o the station. It would have been a wiher pro nlaoed it behind the Opere dadina to have nlac where ground could have been found by the removal of a fow housm in an unimportant stroet.

The phenomenon of the changes in the level of the sea is one which is well shown in the case of the Mediterranean .. A recent brochure presented to.the French Academy of Sciences furnishes interesting information on this point; it being apparent that the sea has greatly in- crensed in depta as compared to ancient times. Forinerly a bridge 3,000 feet long, united Leucade to the Continent. To-day it is sub- merged, but the foundations of the work. were discovered.11 feet benenth the surface. It may therefore be concluded that since the construc- tion of the bridge the sea has risen at this point over, nine feet. Similar incidents have been noted at other points.

Some very curious figures as to the' circula- tion of Paris' journals were lately put forward by a contemporary .. Le Petit Parisien heads the list with 1,500,000, which must make our own "largest circulation in the world" look foolish at its yiuarter of a million, or so. Then eomes Le Petit Journal, with 800,000, closely followed by Le Joarnal, beloved of mondaines (whole and half), with 750,000. Some way after . is the excellent and trustworthy Mutin, with 400,000, and then a terrific drop, until we reach the Anglophil Sicle, with 3,000, That the French know what is good for them in the way of daily mental food may be questioned ; but that they know what they like. there can be no doubt at all.

Time was when France passed for the most sober country, But that is not now. Whatever the cause, the French peasantry have taken on drinking habits which it will require the com- bined efforts of anti alcoholic societies, generals of districts, and other well-meaning and public- spirited personagee to eradicate. The country is and greater sinner than the town. This ia proved by recent statistics, which give the average for Paris as slighty over a pint of wine a day, whereas the figures. are considerably higher for Boulogne, Nice, St. Etienne, Tou- louse, c. At Nice, for instance, the con- surption is a third more.

A foolish midinette, who eloped with Ali Kadour, a colossal Arab from Algeris, has been restored to her sorrowing parents, and her stal- wast and swarthy lover is in the lock-up. .The midinette, a gifl of eighteen, was employed sa. a minor hand and messenger in the establish- 'ment af a fashionable dressmaker, The latter is in the habit of giving.the persom in her employment an annual outing. At the end of last month she took her workpeople of various categories, from the chief dress planners and embroiderers to the youngest of thre,midinettes, to Fontaineblean. The excursion was arranged by a special agency, and Ali Kadont was sebt with the party as guide and general, caretaker. The Arab received as much as £120 for the ex- penses of the excursion . party, and was to return the surplus remaininig over in his hands to the dressmaker. The excursion was Very successful at the outset. The:dressmaker and her girls, old and young, were enchanted, and sat down to dinner in one of the best hotels in Fontaineblean, with splendid appetites. Then all, went to the train for . Paris, and at. a late hour the Gare de Lyon was reach- ed. At this terminus the dressmaker called the roll of her handi, and.it was found that one of the youngest and prettiest of the midinettes had disappeared. So, too had the stalwart Arab guide, and it wan then remembered by some of the girls that the man had been paying special attention during the excursion to the midinette who had vanished. As Ali Kadour had taken . not only the girl, but had also gone away: with the surplus money which he had to return, the dressmaker informed the police. Sho estim- ated the money remaining over in the Arab's possession at about £40. Ali Kadour was arrested yesterday outaide a cafe on: the bou- levards, and the midinette whom he had spirited sway was subsequently found. She was living, not at the Arab's address, for he is a married man with: children, but in a small general lodging-house.

If anyone be on the look-out for a new and not too arduous. .profession, here is one. A certain vagabond, noticeable for his thinness, was recently arrested here for some minor offence. Questioned by the magistrate as to his calling, he declared that he was a "sitter for corpulenoe." Explanation being called for, he protested that he waa. employed by the proprietor of a certain cure for corpulenice (the name of which he gave) to sit for his photograph. In one, subsequently labelled "Before taking so-and-so," he wora beneath his clothes a suit of thin india-rubber dis- tended with air. In the two next photographs, to be-entitled respectively. "After one month" and "After two months," the india-rubber suit was proportionately deflated, while for the . last photograph of. all, 'to be. called "Cured," it was altogether dispensed with.

div.head: Thos. Cook & Son,
div.p: (EGYPT), LIMITED, HEAD OFFICE—LUDGATE CIRCUS—LONDON.
CHIEF EGYPTIAN OFFICE — CAIRO, near SHEPHEARD'S HOTEL.
Alexandria, Port-Said, Suez, Luxor, Assuan, Haifa, & Khartum.
GENERAL RAILWAY AND STEAMSHIP AGENTS. BANKERS.
BAGGAGE AND FORWARDING AGENTS.
Officially appointed & Sole Agents in Cairo to the P.&O. S.N. Co.

RESIDENTS IN EGYPT proceeding to Europe for the summer are requested to apply to our offices for information respecting their Passages, where steamer plans may be consulted and Berths secured by all Lines of Steamers to all parts of the Globe; arrangements can also be made for the collection and forwarding of their baggage and clearance at port of arrival.

CIRCULAR NOTES issued payable at the current rate of exchange in all the principal cities of Europe. Cook's Interpreters in uniform are present at the principal Railway stations and Landing-places in Europe to assist passengers holding their travelling tickets.

Large and splendidly appointed steamers belonging to the Co. leave Cairo thrice weekly, between November and March, for Luxor, Assouan and Wady-Halfa in connection with trains de luxe to Khartoum. Moderate fares.
FREIGHT SERVICE, Steamers leave Cairo every Saturday and Tuesday for Assouan and Halfa.
Special Steamers and Dahabeahs for private parties.
Special arrangements for tour in PALESTINE, SYRIA and the DESERT, Lowest Rates.
Best camp equipment in the country! 10 12-904

div.head: CREDIT LYONNAIS
div.p: Société Anonyme
Capital 250,000,000 de francs
Entièrement Versés
Agences d'Égypte:
Alexandrie, Le Caire, Port-Said
Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.

table.head: HORAIRE DES TRAINS A PARTIR DU 3 NOVEMBRE 1904

div.p: N.B. – Ne seront admis dans les deux trains No 3 et 24, que les voyageurs porteurs de billets de 1re et 2e classe seulement et les abonnés à ces deux classes. Le train No 16 ne s'arrêtera pas les Dimanches au garage Cozzika. – Le train No 22 s'arrêtera les Dimances à Massarah au lieu du train No 18.
N.B. Tous les mardis et les jeudis de chaque semaine, pendant la saison théâtrale à l'Opéra Khédivial le dernier train partira de Bab-el-Louk à 12h.45 au lieu de 12h.30.
